messages.message:
I see what you’re saying, Bas, but the more I dig into it, the less sure I am that there’s an issue here.

First, there is no duplicate page. Google understands that `/pricing-policy/` and `pricing-policy/index.html` point to the same content and source. Google search itself already selects `/pricing-policy/` as the canonical version, so there’s no need I can discern to manually designate it in files.  Certainly if you google AI Hub pricing, no index.html result is returned.

So as I understand the request to mark all index.html files as canonical repeats work Google is already doing, based on the standard way that HTML files work. To me, this seems like a false positive from the tooling.

The only other reason I can see for this issue is if there is a link somewhere that points directly to the index.html instead of to the `pricing-policy` directory, but I couldn’t find any such link in the docs or in the instabase code repo.

yes, google corrects it but scores us down. There is no issue with getting the right results, or the user journey: it dings our authority and health score which makes us having to pay more for ads and harder to rank high. Could we please correct?

I think we’re confused because it’s not like we have 2 pages, one of which could be marked as canonical. There’s just one page. If you hit `/pricing-policy/` with a browser, the browser will implicitly append `index.html` to the the end of that URL, and retrieve the page from `/pricing-policy/index.html`. So both URLs work with the browser, but there’s only one page being served by the site regardless of which URL you hit with the browser.
So it’s not clear to us how to fix Google thinking there are 2 pages, with duplicate content.

@Bas we’re having a hard time figuring out exactly how to fix this in a reasonable way, since if it’s an issue, it would affect literally every index.html page. Can you tell us how you’ve addressed this issue on marketing pages?

I think the other things that would be helpful here would be information about the score and cost differences, as I did not find that information. That would help with prioritization for me.
Spoke with our seo contractor and we can deprioritize this for now
I would still love to get info on how you’ve addressed this in marketing, when you have time. I’m always looking for new information for our toolkit!
